question_stem: The graph of \(y = g(x)\) is shown below. The function \(g(x)\) has a minimum at \((-1, -2)\) and a maximum at \((2, 3)\).

parts.question_text: State the coordinates of the minimum and maximum points of the function \(y = \frac{1}{2}g(x)\).
parts.solution_text:
The transformation \(y = \frac{1}{2}g(x)\) represents a vertical stretch of scale factor \(\frac{1}{2}\).  This means the y-coordinates of all points are halved, while the x-coordinates remain unchanged.

Original minimum: \((-1, -2)\)
New minimum: \((-1, \frac{1}{2} \times -2)\) = \((-1, -1)\)

Original maximum: \((2, 3)\)
New maximum: \((2, \frac{1}{2} \times 3)\) = \((2, \frac{3}{2})\)

Therefore, the minimum point is at \((-1, -1)\) and the maximum point is at \((2, \frac{3}{2})\).
